Heyo! Oliver_Hart here. I've got a long drive ahead of me, and as promised, I'd share with you guys a new story I'm working on. It's MUCH shorter than Beating the Heat, and this is still a work in progress. So I figured that before I head out the door, I'd share what I've got


Liquid Courage - Oliver_Hart [https://pastebin.com/FcRqG5Nc]
So, there's a human, a cheetah, and some crows in this bar...

>Does any story with a happy ending start with alcohol?
>You tap the bar a few times, signaling for another round
>The bartender, a cheetah wearing a crisp white blouse and a pair of jeans, produces a short glass and sets about polishing it
>”You sure about that? You’re gonna regret it in the morning,” she asks
>Wordlessly, you produce a worn $10 bill and drop it into her nearly-empty tip jar
>She shrugs her shoulders and sets a rum and coke before you
>”I don’t get to serve human portions very often. I hope I mixed it right,” she adds with a wink
>Your head swimming and hot, you press the sweating glass to your forehead
>The bartender watches with some degree of confusion
>”If you just wanted something cool, ice is free you know.”
“No, this is fine,” you take a few deep breaths, trying to keep track of your surroundings. “Just need a few minutes.”
>The cheetah leans on the counter
>”Not to sound like a stereotypical bartender or anything, but what’s wrong?”
>You take a meager sip
“Nothing, actually.”
>”You’ve been coming here for a couple days now, and you’re WAY overdressed. Humans don’t just come to the Blinking Light, especially ones who look like they have cash to burn.”

Anonymous Sun 13 Aug 2017 03:31:47 No.10994233 Report
Quoted By: >>10994347 >>10995975
Remember that necessity is the mother of invention. The ultimate predator has no need for a spear, and the thought would never enter its mind. Humans are fairly weak in terms of sheer physical power, but because of that we have to invent ways to make us equal. Bows and nets to kill animals we can't catch. Traps to get food without having to hunt. Tactics and teamwork to kill animals we can't on our own. Cars and just riding other, faster animals to make up for our slower land speed. Clothing and containers to travel to environments that would kill us otherwise. It's important to think about not just how 'smart' an alien/anthro is, but how it is smart.
Food for thought.

On the topic of livable environments, there are few, if any, species that have been able to thrive in as many biomes that humanity has; people like the Inuit live in tundras that usually require very specific adaptations to survive a day while at the same time you have the Bedouin who live on the other side of the earth's temperature range. Humanity has a biological disposition towards living wherever the fuck it wants to.

>>11003523
When you contract "you" and "are" together it's spelled "you're", not "your". "Your" is only for the possessive of "you".

Same vein, "we" and "are" together is "we're", not "were". "Were" is only the plural of "was".

Also your dialogue seems kind of clunky in parts. For instance, immediately after being asked what he's doing in the middle of nowhere, Anon spits out "I am backpacking my way to any city on the west coast, The Midwest is dead. There are no more humans there and my last family member died a month ago. Also, I have no money. There! Is that good enough for you? Now what's your name? You just waterboard random drifters for fun? Your not gonna eat me are you?"

That's just an insane amount of shit for someone to say at basically a moment's notice, and almost none of it seems related. Like, why would he say he has no money, there? He was only asked one question, why is he asking if that's good enough like he's been badgered all day? This seems like a really weird time to ask for a name considering that he's worried about being eaten as well. Also he knows why they poured water over him, he was lying down pretending to be dead in the middle of the desert. Why would he be indignant about that as well? It comes off like you're trying to shove all of your exposition into one line of dialogue which just makes it seem really stilted and awkward.

Alright, I'm back.

>Sleep that night had come hard, and as a result work had been several shades more taxing than it usually was.
>You worked at the factory a couple of blocks down the road from your grotty apartment complex, cranking out machine parts on a production line. Not exactly the cushiest of jobs, but you got paid by rule of piecework, meaning that if you put your back into it, your wages were usually respectable.
>It also involved using equipment that you really, really shouldn't be using when you're dead on your feet.
>You're pretty sure you almost lost a hand when you dozed off using the steel cutter. After that you'd spent the rest of the day avoiding the more dangerous tools, instead busying yourself with more benign jobs.
>So yeah, it'd been a slow day.
>Right now you were dragging yourself up the stairs to your apartment, running on nothing but happy thoughts and that cheap-ass coffee you'd purchased from the factory cafeteria, its taste indistinguishable from motor oil.
>You tried to keep yourself in good spirits by reminding yourself that it was Friday, and that the weekend was finally upon you and you'd snagged that blockbuster Ruth had been raving about from the DVD store on your way back home.
>Sure you were still pissed at her, but considering you and her spent so much time around one another, it was probably a sound idea to extend the olive branch as soon as possible.
>Besides, ever since Ruth had moved in the two of you had christened Friday night 'movie night', and you weren't about to skimp on tradition -- even if you hadn't quite gotten around to forgiving her yet.
>Forcing your way up the last few steps, you reluctantly enter the apartment. Ruth had already left by the time you'd woken up this morning, so this was going to be the first you saw of her today.
>There wasn't a doubt in your mind that the ensuing confrontation would be awkward as fuck.
